data.title: Fly mode in spatial view
data.body:
Hello!

I see that is pretty hard to set the camera to a desirable position (using the gizmos and all). I suggest an "fly mode" when the camera is selected, to position it using a first person point of view, controlling with the mouse to look and WASD keys to move. This feature is similar to the Blender's Shift + F, that allows an easy camera positioning.

And congratulations to the developers for the new release, nice stuff! :smile:

data.title: Option to keep mouse cursor inside window boundaries
data.body:
**Windows 7 - Godot version: V2.1 RC1**

Sorry for not including much information on this, but Godot desperately needs a way to lock
the mouse window inside a window without it making the cursor and mouse stuck in the center of the screen.

This will help both developers and end users and keep away an immense amount of frustration.

Thank you

data.title: Added force_raycast_update GDScript method for RayCast[2D]
data.body: I was wondering why a RayCast2D instance returned the same collision point when I tried to use it multiple times during a single fixed process frame. I wanted an enemy to try and look at multiple players in one frame, and pick the one to follow, but yeah... I'd have to make n raycasters for n players, which doesn't seem optimal. So I added a force_raycast_update() method to make sure the raycast result is "refreshed". This little change saves the need to manually talk to the servers. Took care of RayCast2D and RayCast.

data.title: Crashfix for OSX on Sierra beta

data.title: xform_inv() jitter
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1-rc2 Windows 10
Radeon HD 6960

So I was messing around with code to satisfy #6087 and I found out that xform_inv() jittered my object around (practically it's more like `set_pos(get_parent().get_transform().xform_inv(desired_global_pos))`). Is it connected to #2043 ?

Example scene in the link:
[to_local_world.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/409377/to_local_world.zip)

Explanation:
The goal was to implement a prototype of to_world and to_local methods - basically a transform xform() and an xform_inv(). To see the result I set_pos() a "cursor" polygon.
On my system cursor "ToWorldIndicator" works fine, while "Polygon2D 2" (the one with the script) jiggles around it's stability point. Tested with _process() and _process_fixed().

data.title: Node2D and Spatial .to_world/.to_local(Vector2/Vector3) methods
data.body:
I have come across this issue/idea some time ago, fortunately it wasn't a big project, but now I've noticed this again: there are no "simple" methods for space-vector operations for nodes (jumping between local and global coordinate system with raw vectors). There is a lot of methods for translating and looking_at etc. but imagine this simple scenario:
1. An enemy with an Area2D is walking around the scene, listening for objects
2. Player enters the Area2D, a script receives a proper signal
3. The enemy should now raycast to check if the player is really visible
4. RayCast2D requires a local-space cast coordinate, proper calcuation would be `aimPoint = to_local(PlayerObj.get_global_pos())`

Since there is no function like that the dev has to figure out some matrix math to properly do this, basically wasting time and probably writing buggy code.

My suggestion is to implement four new methods:

```
Vector2 Node2D.to_local(Vector2)
Vector2 Node2D.to_world(Vector2)
Vector3 Spatial.to_local(Vector3)
Vector3 Spatial.to_world(Vector3)
```

`to_local()` transforms a vector to local coordinate system - eg. `to_local(get_global_pos()) -> (0,0)`
`to_world()` transforms a vector to global coordinate system - eg. `to_world(Vector2(0,0)) -> =get_global_pos()`

This would help a lot with game logic that does some more analytic work for other purposes than "looking at" (or at least would enable things like "look at the object, but try to predict it's destination in 50 ms" -> `look_at(Target.to_world(velocity*prediction_time)))`.

Garry's Mod's Wiremod Expression2 language had those two little methods on vectors, thanks to those I never really had to do any matrix math at all. Kind of missing them here.

data.title: Implement version check for export templates
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Any OS, Godot 2.1-stable.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Many users forget to update their export templates when trying a new version of Godot (especially testing releases such as betas and RCs) and end up facing crashes in their exported games.

The editor should have a way to check the version of the export templates, and refuse them if they don't match the editor version.

Alternatively, we could enforce as of 2.2 that templates should be installed in a versioned path, and the editor would only look into the versioned path that matches its version. This would allow to use several versions of Godot with templates concurrently.

data.title: Unable to update shader uniforms for tiles in TileMap
data.body:
Hi, i'm confused about how TileMap works. I have a shader that receives some parameters, when i configure the scene i'm able to set the shader uniforms, but after export it to a tilemap and add it to my scene, the methods for get a tile just returns a vec2 with tile position, so i cannot update the shader uniforms anymore.
What am I doing wrong?

data.title: Cant count more than 70k in 2.1
data.body:
Ubuntu gnome 64bit ; 2.1 rc1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected): the result variable is stuck in 63516, what I expected is... A lot of number ?

Reproduce using this code:

extends Node2D

var test = 1000
var result = 1

func _ready():
    set_process(true)
    pass

func _process(delta):
    while ( test > 1):
        result = result \* test
        test -= 1
    print (result)

_Soon_

Get Tilemap size
data.body: The ability to get the size of the used area in a Tilemap is very useful when generating random dungeons, to avoid over processing in for loops and so.

data.title: It's hard to D&D nodes from scene tree to VS sheet
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 16.04 72748d1363d090f33d5ca6b9c00142b5e8f7d78f

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
It's possible to drag and drop nodes from scene tree to visual script board. 
Unfortunately there is problem with context switching. While for me relatively fast drag always works fine,  it seems on other devices it's very hard to drag node on VS sheet.  I was talking about this with @TheoXD here: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/6075#issuecomment-238337278 He was surprised it's even possible, and he have real problems with doing this, so it's probably somehow resolution/fps/system dependent.

I think **context should be switched only when 'mouse_press_up' event occurs** inside scene tree tab.

data.title: Ability to copy VS nodes between scripts
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
72748d1363d090f33d5ca6b9c00142b5e8f7d78f

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
**UPDATE: it's possible to duplicate nodes with ctrl+D, so only 'between scripts' part is left.**

It would be awesome if we could just select and copy VS nodes (multiple ones as well as single one).
Also, copying nodes should be possible between different VS scripts.

This would allow us to create a 'palette' of the most commonly used nodes so we didn't need to find them in top down menu all the time. It would make working with VS a little more similar how painters work in graphic program, where they are making small palette of colors in a handy place and they are using a sampler when they want to change color.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Ability to find function fast in VS
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
72748d1363d090f33d5ca6b9c00142b5e8f7d78f

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Currently in VS when we want to use function from node, we have to go into inspector tab and deal with a long list of functions. At the moment there is no way to use keyboard to faster find what we are looking for:
![manyfunc](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/17480413/17004da6-5d78-11e6-906c-908310aebc68.png)

It would be a lot better if we could use fuzzy matching to find this function faster. It would be even more better if we could do this from inside VS editor, **without** looking for Inspector tab (**which is not visible** anyway when we are working with VS in fullscreen). 
I imagine it could look more or less like this:
![fuzzy_function](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/17480506/84b50a44-5d78-11e6-8759-d39a17190f8e.png)

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Better rendering of VS nodes when they are positioned in top to down manner
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
72748d1363d090f33d5ca6b9c00142b5e8f7d78f

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Currently VS layout force on programmer straight horizontal left to right positioning of VS nodes. 
There is nothing wrong with that, but basically every VS script will also need to allow position nodes under each other (lets say new line), currently representation for this scenario is not very readable:
![topdown1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/17479646/ee788884-5d73-11e6-8bf2-d86e85ae8359.png)

![topdown2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/17479650/f1ae57a4-5d73-11e6-88a9-4394f7cf5565.png)

I think there are three ways of solving this,
1. Have lines connection that acts a little more like bezier curves:
![betterlines](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/17479813/0c84a032-5d75-11e6-9884-4daf51af6113.png)
2. When there is no way to avoid another VS node, line could get little more alpha in that part:
![betterlines1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/17480054/49e12102-5d76-11e6-8785-8fe1ce66a31c.png)
3. Dynamically move output connection points in response to VS node movement:
![betterlines2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/17479910/92933e86-5d75-11e6-8379-37e8ff072121.png)

Obviously mix of those three would be the best.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Add a play overlay on video thumbnails in asset detailed view
data.body:
Currently the assetlib web frontend will properly add such an overlay, but Godot's frontend won't.

View in the web frontend:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4701338/17478290/12421d06-5d6b-11e6-86de-156a65e20be9.png)

Something similar should be done in the C++ frontend, so that people don't have to add this overlay manually like @kubecz3k did in https://godotengine.org/asset-library/frontend/asset/edit/14

data.title: Better custom EditorPlugin nodes
data.body:
Nodes created by the `add_custom_type` function in EditorPlugin have the selected script assigned to it when adding. This makes them almost useless, as you can only use the functions defined in that script in other nodes.

This is completely different from other nodes and makes node addons pretty much useless/much more annoying to use.
